I have a question, how does Jenkins compare to these. It is equivalent to Gulp and Grunt, or it solves different problems?

Continuous Integration (CI): the art of "usually" deploying your  solution automatically upon a certain trigger (usually a push to a specific branch or upon specific time AKA nightly builds).

Task runners: most of the client-side world is now not that "one or two script tags and CSS includes" like we used to have before, but there are way way more libraries and actions that you usually do upon deploying or running your solution.

for example, minifying your CSS and JS files, combining multiple JS files into one file to save HTTP requests, Linting your JS code to detect errors, and many more examples.
each one of these actions can be defined as a "Task" in (for example) Gulp.

task runners like gulp streamlines these tasks and gives you the ability to order, create dependencies, and run tasks upon triggers (most commonly like code changes) and even deploy your changes via FTP.

Hope it helps :)
